top_comment.author: Chris R.

comments.text:
It doesn't seem like rocket science to figure out that if you treat people 
like animals for years, even decades, focusing on punishing them and 
causing as much pain as possible (and letting the prisoners inflict as much 
pain as possible on each other as well), then broken people come out and 
are more likely to repeat the same crimes or do worse -- ergo, the high 
recidivism; on the other hand, if you treat the *criminal behavior* as the 
symptom of an underlying problem -- a broken home life, poverty, a moment 
of uncontrolled rage (as you suggested), or any number of other things -- 
and you treat the prisoners like human beings, giving them educations, 
helping them actualize themselves as human beings, then what comes out at 
the end of the sentence is generally going to be a better, healthier human 
being who isn't likely to murder, rape, rob, or commit other crimes again. 
 Of course, that won't always work, and there are some people who are just 
frakkin' messed up and will either have to be kept under lock and key or 
will commit their crime of choice again, but you will catch a *lot* of 
others who might otherwise not be such bad people but who had problems they 
didn't know how or have the resources to deal with.

But, like I said, it isn't rocket science, and the U.S. government and 
state governments *know* this to be true.  Sweden and Norway and closing 
prisons down, not because of lack of funding but because of lack of 
prisoners.  In the U.S., on the other hand, private corporations get to use 
prisoners as slave labor, get money from the governments to house and keep 
and prisoners (most of the money, of course, going into their pockets 
rather than into appropriate resources from the prisoners), and as a 
result, we can't seem to find enough money to fund the prisons that we 
have, which are just packed to the brim with people.  Not every state has 
private prisons -- thankfully, mine doesn't -- but we still treat them 
basically like animals, and it's not fair.  Every time a person's raped or 
killed by an ex-convict, my first thought is, "Lot of good those years in 
prison did that person, and now someone completely innocent's suffering for 
our need to punish and to feel superior."
comments.author: Alaric Holmes

comments.text:
+Alaric Holmes Yeah I noticed the countries with the worst crime rates 
usually have the harsher sentences and prisons while the countries with the 
lowest crime rates usually have the least crime. It's pretty obvious what 
needs to be done.

I noticed a lot of the crime was done in the heat of the moment too. 
Usually after an argument or being on drugs. A mistake which often lasts 
seconds should never end in 20 years in prison and then death.
comments.author: mrdojob

comments.text:
It doesn't surprise me that some people who're in for violent crimes might 
become better people in time -- or might have always been good people who 
fell into terrible circumstances.  Or just happen to be of the wrong race 
-- but then we get into the issue of guilt vs. innocence again.  It's 
another reason why I oppose the death penalty.  The past is the past, and 
while people should pay their debts to society when they've done wrong, 
that debt need not be viciously exacted, in regard to the horrendous prison 
system, but if they're killed -- well, that's it.  There's no chance for 
them to contribute something better later on.  Frankly, I'm in favor a 
system more like Norway's.

And yes, society will always have enemies, and if there aren't any real 
enemies, certain elements within the society, somewhere near the top, will 
create them -- or even just create the illusion of an enemy (per false flag 
operations).  As long as there's a "them," then there will always be people 
willing to do whatever it takes, give whatever they have to, in order to be 
counted among "us."
comments.author: Alaric Holmes

comments.text:
+Alaric Holmes You can't reason with the unreasonable. Some people (more 
than I would like) are very simple. I met a large number of people in 
prison who actually had a fantastic moral compass compared to people on the 
outside. One of the most charitable and friendly was actually a guy on his 
22nd year for murder.

Society as a whole always has a group of people they hate and always will. 
Sometimes the hated group varies in why they're hated but I think it comes 
down to "them" and "us" mainly because it gives them a greater sense of 
worth.
comments.author: mrdojob

comments.text:
Exactly.  There's absolutely *zero* sense in the death penalty.  It's never 
deterred anyone from committing any of those types of crimes, and it 
doesn't make any sense morally.  "You killed someone, so to show everyone 
how wrong killing is, we're gonna kill you.  That'll learn ya!"  But, no, 
it has nothing to do with any coherent sense of justice and everything to 
do with the satisfaction of seeing someone punished.  Karen Wynn, a 
researcher at Yale, has been doing studies on babies and their inherent 
sense of morality, and she's determined that babies are born with a 
rudimentary sense of morality, but not all of it "good."  Basically, their 
morality touches on the entire spectrum of human morality but in very 
simplistic, very direct ways.  And one of the things almost all babies and 
young toddlers have in common is the sense of wanting to see someone 
punished for doing something that they see as wrong.  My point in all of 
this is that the death penalty strikes me as reflecting the fact that a lot 
of people never really mature beyond that stage of development -- "You do 
bad stuff, we do bad stuff to you!" -- but, yes, in more "adult" minds, 
there's added sense of "superiority," the need to distinguish oneself from 
others ("us" vs. "them") as much as possible -- and what's a clearer way of 
demonstrating that someone else is so much more evil than you are than 
"executing" them?

And, yes, I'd agree that there are a lot of people who are perfectly 
willing to hand over everything to the police state in order for a 
guarantee of "safety" and "justice," both of which fall by the wayside once 
the police state has you.  I mean, look at the dichotomous reactions to Ed 
Snowden's revelations: some, like me, view him as a hero; others view him 
as a traitor for "betraying his oath" (even though his oath was to the 
Constitution, not the government -- but a lot of people consider one's 
loyalties to the "brotherhood," so to speak, as being more important than 
loyalty to the very ideals that that brotherhood is supposed to represent 
and defend).

A lot of the rest of us, I'm sorry to say, feel powerless to do anything 
short of violence, and unless everyone rose up at once, the armed forces 
would quash any rebellion very quickly....  Not to mention, I'm not overly 
eager for civil war -- I'd rather try to reason with my fellow Americans 
than kill them any day of the week.
comments.author: Alaric Holmes

comments.text:
+Alaric Holmes The most scary part is that a lot of US citizens are so 
hungry for blood they don't care if they sleep walk into a police state.

I largely think that the death penalty is only around because of the sense 
superiority it gives people when they read about it in the news paper.

A "them" and "us" culture is really noticeable in English speaking nations 
but mostly the US.
comments.author: mrdojob

comments.text:
Dude, that's rough.  Can't imagine....  It truly is unconscionable how we 
treat our prisoners.  Just setting aside the issue of guilt or innocence 
for a moment, we've been privatizing our prisons to such a degree that it's 
now *profitable* to keep throwing people in prison over nothing-crimes, 
like smoking pot or whatever.  Not only that, but in addition to having 25% 
of the world's prison population, we're also pretty high up there among 
nations that use solitary confinement -- and we do it willy-nilly.  Pretty 
much every little infraction -- BAM!  Solitary confinement!  The 
imprisonment of Leonard Peltier, who's been in solitary for *decades*, is 
just one of the most egregious examples, but he's certainly not the only 
one.  Actually, just recently, it turned out that some guy in Arizona who 
was arrested for a DWI (driving while intoxicated, if that acronym's not 
used where you are), and he was put into solitary because of a "suicide 
risk," and then he was "lost in the system" and spent *two years* in a 
solitary cell.  Unbefuckinglievable.  

I'm telling you, man, this nation, the US, is becoming scarier and scarier, 
and what's worse than anything is how neatly the police state has been 
hidden under the veneer of civilization.
comments.author: Alaric Holmes

comments.text:
+Alaric Holmes I wish people understood the misery of being stuck in a 
prison cell. I was sent to prison for months and it was horrible. The 
thought of being stuck in prison for 15+ years and then being killed is 
something even I can't imagine but probably have a better understanding 
that most.

I'm stunned really by how humans can condemn another to that kind of fate.
comments.author: mrdojob

comments.text:
To be fair, I'm not an expert on the law, and there may be some special 
exemptions, but as I understand it, the basic idea is that the appellate 
and Supreme courts don't try the case again, only review the merits of the 
original trial.  And, yes, you'd think that a nation this powerful would be 
smart enough to recognize the serious problems with this system, but... 
well, might doesn't always (or often) make right.  :^(
comments.author: Alaric Holmes

comments.text:
+Alaric Holmes You would have thought that people who have so much power 
would be smart enough to discover this obvious flaw. I heard of something 
similar but I never knew it applied to the death penalty too.
comments.author: mrdojob

comments.text:
Collecting it, presenting it...  Pretty much, an appeal is a review of the 
trial solely on its own merits, not on the any new evidence.  However, I 
should note that, due to the U.S.'s double jeopardy law, if the trial 
itself was found to have flaws and the appellate court vacates the 
conviction, there can't be a new trial and the person goes free.  Still, 
though, no new evidence.
comments.author: Alaric Holmes

comments.text:
+Alaric Holmes So they only look at errors in collecting evidence and not 
the evidence itself?
comments.author: mrdojob

comments.text:
As an American, I totally agree.  Unfortunately, new evidence can't be 
introduced at an appeal -- stupid as that may sound.  Only at retrial can 
new evidence be brought.  So, if the DNA was suppressed during the trial, 
it can't be tested and brought up at appeal.  Totally, totally stupid.  The 
appeal only concerns the merits of the case itself.  The only way to get 
around that would be if it could be shown that the DNA *should* have been 
tested (on *legal* grounds, as in prosecutorial or judicial misconduct -- 
of course, it should *always* be tested), and that would result in a 
retrial, but that's not common.  Proving misconduct is not easy here where 
corruption runs rampant.
comments.author: Alaric Holmes

Yes, I think you failed to understand this. We are talking about people 
proved to be innocent, which is no short order. It's incredibly difficult 
to demonstrate innocence to the point that a court accepts it, and that 
means scientific certainty of innocence. (It is worth noting that it is 
technically harder to prove your innocence, than it is to prove your guilt 
in the first place, because there is a higher standard of evidence).

comments.text:

comments.author: MrDodger3222

comments.text:
+jtlbb2 
You're conflating personal desire and the philosophy of governance.  Do I 
personally think he should have been allowed to live (setting aside the 
fact that his death sentence no doubt cost this country more monetarily 
than a life sentence would have) -- or, to phrase it more generally, do I 
want people who do the sorts of things that he did to continue living?  My 
gut response is to say no, but again I find that I keep asking myself, What 
is gained by killing him?  And by killing him, are we losing some potential 
good later on (such as, for instance, if he turned himself around in prison 
and began helping other prisoners who *weren't* condemned to life in prison 
to become better people)?

Again, in case my answer is unclear, my gut reaction is to say no, someone 
who's committed such terrible crimes has no real right to continue living; 
and if I were a lover, friend, or relative of one of the people he'd 
murdered, I'd very likely be on the front line screaming for his head or 
applying for the job of executioner just so I could flip the switch.

However, that's not the point of this at all.  The point is, I do not 
believe that it is the role of the government to avenge people; rather, it 
is the role of the government to administer justice.  Then the question is, 
is death a just response to one or more acts of cold blooded murder? 
 Provided that the person isn't mentally ill or debilitated (and thus not 
responsible for his or her actions), in an ideal world, perhaps it would be 
-- but this isn't an ideal world, not even close.  With all of the doubt 
that exists in our justice system, with all of its corruption and its 
multi-tiered nature, a civilized society cannot justly inflict death as a 
punishment for a crime unless the government can be 100% sure with 
incontrovertible evidence that the defendant is guilty (not simply beyond a 
reasonable doubt but beyond any possible doubt whatsoever).  If one 
innocent person is murdered by the state, then it nullifies the legitimacy 
of all the state-sanctioned murders of guilty people, because then we're 
just murdering people because the law says we can.

And there is yet another question: What does execution get us as a society, 
other than the warm and fuzzy feeling anyone gets after a blood sacrifice 
to cleanse ourselves?  Is it a deterrent?  It doesn't appear to be.  So, 
what really is gained by the society as a whole from execution that we 
could otherwise get with life imprisonment without the possibility of 
parole, other than less money spent on the latter?
comments.author: Alaric Holmes

comments.text:
+Alaric Holmes
So do you really think someone like Ted Bundy should have been allowed to 
live? Bundy killed at least 3 dozen women. How many do you think begged him 
to let them live, but he killed them anyway? I guarantee that whatever 
"torture" Bundy felt in his final moments, it was 100% more humane than any 
of his victims.

Why should someone like Bundy still get to eat food, read books, etc but 
his victims will never able to experience any of these things ever again. 
Did his victims get a last meal? No.
comments.author: jtlbb2

comments.text:
If the criminal justice system were infallible, that argument would be 
reasonable despite my not agreeing with it.  However, it's too often the 
case that everyone's convinced that so-and-so did such-and-such until it's 
finally proved that they didn't -- hopefully, not *after* they've already 
been murdered.

While I empathize with the desire not to let people like that out again, 
the inescapable fact is that life-imprisonment is less expensive for the 
state than the death penalty -- unless you want to take away the right to 
appeal -- and other nations, like Norway and Sweden, have had a lot of luck 
in rehabilitating people who've committed terrible crimes (not to mention 
reducing the number of crimes like those committed in the first place) and 
lowering the recidivism rate dramatically.

The desire for revenge is a strong one and one that is apparently, if 
studies done on babies over the last decade or so, inherent to the human 
sense of morality, but using the state to enact such revenge doesn't appear 
to do much for the good of society as a whole.  It doesn't deter people, 
and more innocent people get executed than should ever be the case in a 
civilized nation.
comments.author: Alaric Holmes

comments.text:
I'm not against the death penalty if someone willingly killed another 
human, for serial killers as well there is no rehabilitation, rapists and 
killer should be put down. I definitely wouldn't want these people back out 
on the streets I hate the idea of offering parole to these idiots, they 
know one way of life and they'll go back to it as soon as life gets tough.
comments.author: G Tanda

comments.text:
I want to know your out look on the death penalty if an inmate ever did 
anything to a person you love.. (touch wood it never ever happens..)
comments.author: ALEX THEKID

comments.text:
Most of us love to be ignorant to all the facts. That's why we are failing 
at almost every turn.
comments.author: comedyloverism

top_comment.author: Barney Stinson

comments.text:
Lie detectors don't detect lies, they pick the body's response to 
DECEPTION. theat's why they are inadmissible in court.
comments.author: Carter Stokoe

comments.text: Those aren't always correct
comments.author: Aspen Lillyflow

comments.text: +jenniferthomas28 yes, that is true
comments.author: mandy

comments.text: +jenniferthomas28 Hmm interesting point
comments.author: Barney Stinson

comments.text:
also sometimes people fail a lie detector when they are telling the truth 
because they were afraid it might say they were lying
comments.author: jenniferthomas28

comments.text: drugs and sociopaths can bypass it, also 1/3 people can pass a lie detector
comments.author: TheBrownSurvivor

comments.text:
Lie detectors produce false positives.Also, certain people know how to 
manipulated them.
comments.author: Hannah Griffith-Smith

comments.text:
Those things are very inaccurate. In regards to blaming the prosector for 
getting them sentenced, you need to bear in mind that this is the way the 
criminal justice system works, you can't just prosecute someone because 
they seem like they're guilty or acquit someone because they seem good 
natured. Prosecutors have to use every argument available to them to make 
the suspect seem guilty and vice versa for the defence, and from their 
exchange the judge and jury get an idea of what happened and decide on 
guilt and innocence. If the prosecutor is too soft then a guilty person 
might look innocent, and if the attorney is soft then an innocent person 
could end up looking guilty.

More so than that, I think a big reason for the wrong verdict being handed 
down is because of mishandling of evidence, corruption and bias. Those are 
the issues that need to be handled. Inspectors need to take better 
precautions when handling evidence to avoid contamination, detectives, 
judges and the jury need to not be bias based on appearance/religion etc, 
and there needs to be precautions in place to prevent crooked cops from 
setting someone up as the culprit so it looks like they are doing their job 
e.g. torturing a confession
comments.author: jenniferthomas28

comments.text:
1/3 people can pass a lie detector, and then there is the logical debate on 
using the devil's breath.
comments.author: TheBrownSurvivor

top_comment.text:
Being found not guilty isn't the same thing as innocent... were they found 
innocent?  Not likely﻿
top_comment.author: G Nauck

comments.text:
It will, and many years from now possibly centuries that's the way it will 
be...
comments.author: Great Scott

comments.text: +rick james Yeaah that will work our great Im sure..................
comments.author: Andreas karlsson

comments.text:
+G Nauck they should leave the courts out of it, let the man do the justice 
for his wife and family, after a short time of criminals knowing that their 
dropping like flies because people can take justice in their own hands, 
that's deterrent right there
comments.author: Great Scott

comments.text:
+G Nauck 
I didn't mean to suggest that executions are designed to "undo" anything. 
 Rather, what I was saying was that, because we as a society can't "undo" 
any *punishments* that we dole out, and because our criminal justice system 
is fallible and we *WILL* falsely convict people of crimes from time to 
time (whether by malfeasance or by an honest misinterpretation of available 
evidence), while time spent in prison cannot be given back to the falsely 
convicted person, they will have the rest of their life to live as they see 
fit (and perhaps money granted to them via a lawsuit against the state for 
wrongful imprisonment -- it seems only fair to me that the rest of their 
life should be easier, at least financially); however, an execution *cannot* 
be undone, and a dead prisoner, no matter how much they are exonerated, 
cannot walk again.  And that is the injustice of the death penalty that I 
meant to illustrate.

That's all that I was getting at, but if my wording was confusing, I 
apologize.  I'm glad we can agree that executions fail to achieve their 
stated goals.  I would say that it is for several reasons, not the least of 
which is the fallibility of our system.  However, even then, I don't see 
how murdering someone in response to a terrible act truly benefits a 
society.  I will be fair and say that I've never had the horrific 
experience of having someone I love murdered by someone, and I can expect 
that I would wish death on the person who murdered that loved one if I had 
such an experience.  However, I think that a society should reflect the 
best of humanity rather than its basest urges and desires, of which revenge 
is one.  It's perfectly reasonable for a person to want another person dead 
when the latter has murdered someone dear to the former; I'm just not sure 
that society at large should be in the business of making such things 
happen.  Furthermore, the death penalty has never served as a deterrent; 
people have murdered and done other terrible things for as long as 
societies have existed, and I don't think it's fair to suggest that the 
only thing that's kept the majority of people from killing each other is 
fear of death specifically -- perhaps fear of punishment factors in, but 
not death specifically.  I rather think that most people don't kill other 
people because they have senses of morality/ethics that tell them it's 
wrong to murder another person.  All the death penalty does is add more 
murder to the mix than would otherwise be there -- but that's just my 
opinion.

How it's applied -- that is to say, to crimes that poorer people are more 
likely to commit, especially given that even when rich people commit 
murder, they're often spared the sentence of death -- is also an issue well 
worth considering in regard to its effectiveness, but I'd say that the 
two-tiered justice system proves my earlier point about its ineffectiveness 
rather than suggesting that there'd be a more perfect way of utilizing the 
practice.
comments.author: Alaric Holmes

comments.text:
+WillTheWolfLover so in your mind the man that sneaks into your home and 
beats your wife to death with a crowbar should be on the street quicker 
than the man that shots said guy for revenge?

I don't think you get the point of jail.   You know it is supposed to be a 
deterrent, it is supposed to rehabilitate and it is supposed to take 
dangerous people off the street?

A vengeful person will not be deterred, they are acting like a normal 
human, and they are only a harm to those that have harmed them.

You are using the prison system for a socially acceptable version of 
revenge.

comments.author: WillTheWolfLover

comments.text:
+Alaric Holmes
I don't believe executions are designed to undo a crime.  They are designed 
to prevent further crimes as a deterrent and by removing an individual from 
society.   And to provide a soothing effect on the society/victims family.  
Of course they fail in a number of fashions but is that because it doesnt 
work or the way we do it doesnt work?
comments.author: G Nauck

comments.text:
But the question is, then, knowing that that is the nature of reality, that 
we humans will be wrong, Do we murder people that we've convicted of 
certain crimes?  While you can't technically "undo" *any* punishment that 
you give -- that is, you can't give someone back X number of years of their 
life after they've serves that time after having been falsely convicted, 
but you can let them out; you can't unkill someone.
comments.author: Alaric Holmes

comments.text:
It's always going to be that same dilemma..where they think they got the 
facts news and evidence ..and then find out later they fucked up...it's 
human human nature :/ even for the smartest and powerful of ppl
comments.author: Katmanduxo1991

comments.text:
How, exactly, is having it shown that one's DNA does not match the DNA 
found at the scene of a crime *not* proving that person's innocence? 
 Courts and juries don't "find" people innocent, only "guilty" or "not 
guilty" (as the continuation of proceedings implies that there's sufficient 
evidence for the state to believe that the defendant was involved -- 
although, apparently, it also implies that possibility that a prosecutor 
has withheld evidence); charges are dropped when evidence is brought forth 
that the defendant was *not* involved and thus *innocent*.  A criminal act 
is committed, on the other hand, when prosecutors withhold evidence that 
would exonerate the defendant and prove that person *innocent*.

So, to answer your utterly ludicrous question, *yes*, these victims of 
state-sanctioned murder have been found innocent and by all rights the 
charges should've been dropped, and a lot of prosecutors and/or judges are 
guilty of murder!
comments.author: Alaric Holmes

comments.text:
Well..when the evidence is the thing that convicted most....then the

comments.text:
+Dylan Lacey Dylan,since you don't seem arrogant in your opinions,ill 
answer in kind.i am a strong supporter of capitol punishment for 2 
reasons.1,I truly do believe in an eye for an eye!;and 2,I believe for the 
most part it does send a clear message.no,it is not a 100% deterrant,and 
yes,it does cost more.i used to think it was a liberal/conservative 
thing,but its really not! while yes,many liberal political candidates do 
run on a pledge to end it,while many conservatives run on very law and 
order campaigns and do plan to expand it,i know liberals who strongly 
support it,and I know conservatives who strongly oppose it! I live in 
Idaho,idaho is probably one of the most conservative states in America.you 
could probably fit all the liberals in that state in an arbys and still 
have breathing room,and I myself am a moderate to conservative 
republican.we have the death penalty and for cop killers it is 
mandatory,but for other murder convictions it is optional,and judges or 
juries award it about 50/50! I don't know what the best solution really 
is.i support the death penalty,but I would be willing to go along with 
abolishing it if we had truth in sentencing laws and life in prison meant 
life in prison.so I can see both sides.but I do have 1 question,and I hope 
I don't come off as arrogant,and in case I do I ahead of time apologize,but 
here goes:if the death penalty is not a deterrant,how come Michael moore 
isn't dead and im not on death row?
comments.author: Bob Mowreader

comments.text:
It costs more to execute people than to imprison them for life. If you are 
conservative, I recommend you look into this. Also, there is no evidence 
that execution deters crime. 
European countries and Australia and New Zealand have abolished the death 
penalty and have much lower murder rates than the United States, for 
example. 
An exception would be Russia, which has abolished execution but maintains a 
high crime rate.
From a philosophical standpoint, I understand the sense of a need of 
revenge or justice against very evil criminals. I respect that viewpoint, 
but I think it is outweighed by the moral necessity that our governments be 
better than the criminals they purport to condemn.
comments.author: Ben Ghazi

comments.text:
+Todd Zelin  That's such a nice offer. I would consider it and start 
packing if I was younger. I have 4 kids and 7 grandkids and a husband so

responsibilities. Good luck to you : )

comments.text:
+kristabella222
Agreed on all points. Part of why I'm moving abroad for at least a while.
comments.author: Todd Zelin

comments.text:
+Todd Zelin  I understand your point now and I completely agree. It does 
seem the wrongly convicted only get attention when they receive a death 
sentence. Which is unfortunate since there have been so many cases of 
prosecutorial misconduct, lying and mistaken eyewitnesses, etc. Mistakes 
happen and innocent people get sent to prison, often for life. Sometimes 
crimes are so horrible that the death penalty would seem the only 
punishment but I agree that our system is too flawed to have that as an 
option. There are groups that help inmates that aren't given the death 
penalty but it's very hard to get them to review a case. Our justice system 
is pretty screwed up and so many are in prison for non-violent drug 
offenses. There are just too many people in prison that shouldn't be there.
comments.author: kristabella222

comments.text:
+kristabella222
TL;DR: I'm pro killing certain elements of society for the good of the 
whole, but it's obvious that our process gets it wrong way too often to be 
given such a power. They don't even wield imprisonment with the discretion 
it deserves.
comments.author: Todd Zelin

comments.text:
+kristabella222
Oh no, that's not what I meant at all. I should've been more clear but I 
didn't want to invest the time in writing a short article.

My point is even if we stop executing people we'll still be sending tens of 
thousands of innocent people to prison every year and that the appeals 
process is fundamentally broken, not to mention the way trials are carried 
out.

Anyway, I said what I said because sometimes I worry that people will stop 
paying attention when the death penalty goes away, they barely care about 
innocents being executed so I don't imagine anyone gives a shit when they 
just sit in prison forever.
comments.author: Todd Zelin

comments.text:
+Todd Zelin   I'm not sure what point you're trying to make. You seem to be 
saying since the appeal process is only to make sure that the trial was 
fair, we should cut costs and have no appeals, which don't work in your 
opinion. What I'm saying is that without some process in place to keep 
inmates from being executed right away those that are innocent would be 
dead by the time new evidence came to light. Groups like the Innocence 
Project have found DNA evidence that exonerated the condemned. Sometimes 
trials are unfair and evidence was suppressed and a new trial is ordered 
but the evidence was so faulty to begin with that there is no new trial and 
the person goes free.

The thought of sentencing someone to death and then executing them shortly 
after sentencing is horrifying. Our justice system makes mistakes so I hope 
you weren't suggesting that the only thing wrong with the death penalty is 
that we don't kill them fast enough.
comments.author: kristabella222

comments.text:
+kristabella222
My point is they only get a second chance if you can prove the trial was 
unfair, their innocence is not important under the law.
i.e. if you prove someone is absolutely without a shadow of a doubt 
innocent but you can't prove that his trial was unfair, he will be executed
comments.author: Todd Zelin

comments.text:
+Todd Zelin That's true, but it does give time to find evidence of 
innocence if it exists. There have been exonerations after years on death 
row. If not for the appeal process these men would have already been 
executed.
comments.author: kristabella222

comments.text:
+kristabella222 It's only so expensive because of the appeal process, which 
doesn't work anyways. Direct quote from an appellate court judge in a case 
I wrote an article on: "What difference does it make if he's innocent, I'll 
only hear evidence in regards to the fairness of his trial."
comments.author: Todd Zelin

comments.text:

So steve, if it was your life ended wrongly the public should make light of

comments.text:
+Steve Franklin 1. The 142 is since 1970 and vastly less people have been 
executed than in earlier years of the United States.
2. You're assuming that the 142 includes all who are innocent, which it 
should be obvious it doesn't. It's just those who were found by the courts 
to not be guilty. So it is the absolute minimum possible and by no means an 
accurate reflection.
3. Assuming your flawed statistics were accurate; how is a low percentage 
of innocents 'not bad'? If something terrible happens rarely that doesn't 
justify it.

title: Final Meals of Innocent Executed Inmates
